newsitem.title: SWITZERLAND: Berner sees loss, expects improvements.
newsitem.headline: Berner sees loss, expects improvements.

text.p: Berner Allgemeine Holding AG, the parent company of Berner insurance group, said its holding produced a loss of 26.0 million Swiss francs ($18.2 million) on 1996 results, but hoped it would produce better returns in 1997 and 1998.
"Based on the outlook today, one can expect an operating profit which will allow for an appropriate dividend," Berner said in an outlook included with details of 1996 results.
Based on accounts carried forward from the previous year, it produced a net loss of 23.3 million francs for 1996.
It said it would concentrate its activities on the Swiss market, especially private customers.
Its main short-term goal called for cost reduction.
In May Berner said it planned to take provisions of 44.1 million Swiss francs to divest itself of its activities in Spain, where it had a partial stake in Spanish insurer Amaya.
It also proposed omitting its dividend on 1996 results, after it paid 28 francs per share last year.
Its group premium income rose 9.5 percent to 1,262.4 Swiss francs in 1996.
Allianz Holding AG, the German insurer, holds a majority stake in Berner.
